content:
If you've forgotten your email password, the first step is to utilize your email provider's password recovery options. Typically, this involves going to gmail.com, yahoo.com, OR whatever your provider is, then clicking "Forgot Password" on the login page. After that, you are just following the prompts to verify your identity.

Once that is done, you can re-enter it into thunderbird. You Can go to Settings -> Privacy and Security, Saved Passwords to remove the old one and add the new one.
creator: Thundamike

creator: siffemoz

content:
Solution 3 if you are using POP, and I think you might well be as you are talking of a popstate.dat file, is disable your email scanning component in your antivirus (Norton in particular has troubles with pop mail). The antivirus encounters a malformed email, which is usually spam, and instead of moving on it crashes. Than a little later (15 minutes by default) the same email download again and when it gets to the problem one it crashes again. Each crash results in a timeout, not a got mail event, so Thunderbird never gets to update its popstate.dat file that it got any email.

BTW, I have no idea how to implement your solution 2. There is no function to do that as far as I am aware.

I do have to wonder if you moved your old mail data to your new device https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer or if you set everything up afresh and now the new Thunderbird is now downloading your archived mail from the last however long because you never deleted any of it from the server. That would be entirely normal, but there are folk who think that because they know they have seen it they can tell the server to just get mail after a certain date. POP does not work that way it just gets everything that is waiting on the server that that installation has not already retrieved.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
re : I can not find a Help button for general questions

'Help' can be found in two places and nothing has changed in a long time. You can access it via the Menu app icon OR via the 'Menu Bar' toolbar.

In Thunderbird Via 'Menu app icon':

  • Click on the 'Menu app icon' (it has 3 horizontal lines and located on the Unified Toolbar - right side) to see drop down list
  • Select 'Help' and click on 'Get Help'

In Thunderbird via 'Menu Bar' toolbar If you cannot see the 'Menu Bar' toolbar you may need to enable it.

To enable the 'Menu Bar' toolbar

  • Click on the 'Menu app icon' (it has 3 horizontal lines and located on the Unified Toolbar - right side) to see drop down list
  • Click on 'View' > click on 'Toolbars' > click on 'Menu Bar'

The Menu Bar toolbar will appear and 'Help' is the last menu item from left to right.

  • Click on 'Help' then click on 'Get Help'

It will open a new tab in browser on this forum. You can choose to browse through Help Articles or specific topics or Ask a question.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re : I now I can not find a way to send another email to her

Above the Folder Pane where you see the list of mail accounts and their folders is the 'Folder Pane Header' The Folder Pane Header' contains the following from left to right: A cloud icon which means 'Get Messages' In the middle is a large '+New Message' button which means click on me and it will open a new Write message so you can create an email.

If you cannot see that 'Folder Pane Heade' toolbar then maybe you closed it. To display it again:

  • Click on the 'Menu app icon' (it has 3 horizontal lines and located on the Unified Toolbar - right side) to see drop down list
  • click on 'View' > click on 'Folders' > click on 'Folder Pane Header'

Click on '+New Message' button A new Write message window opens. In 'To' field enter email address OR use the 'Contacts Sidebar' where you can select an address book, ten select name of person and clickon 'Add to TO' button.

Type a suitable brief topic in the Subject line Now you can compose your email. To add an image:

  • click on 'Insert' to see drop down options
  • Click on 'Image'
  • click on 'Choose File'
  • Locate the image and select the image file and click on openenter alternative text and click on OK

content:
Thanks, Carroll.

You have two profiles. Now we want to know if one of them has your accounts and messages. Please do this:

  1. Open Thunderbird. If you see the window for setting up an account, click "Cancel".
  2. Are your accounts and messages there? I don't think so. Then continue ...
  3. "Help" menu > "Troubleshooting information" > "about:profiles".
  4. Identify the profile that is *not* in use.
  5. Click on "Launch profile in new browser" below the information for that profile.
  6. Are your accounts and messages there?

I am guessing that neither profile has your accounts and messages. So ...

Did you ever put a profile in a non-standard location?

What has changed on your computer recently? A Thunderbird upgrade? A new computer? Something else?

Do you have a back-up copy of the profile with your accounts and message (or of your whole drive)? (You should!)

Have you been using local folders in Thunderbird or are all your messages in server folders (accessible through webmail)?

Is your e-mail account a POP or IMAP account? Do you have more than one account? Are they all POP, all IMAP, or a mix?

While we continue working on Thunderbird, can you do what you need to in e-mail through webmail (at your e-mail service provider's site)?

content:
Sorry if you already know some of the following information. I cannot tell from your message how much experience you have with Thunderbird.

The Thunderbird application and data are separate. Thunderbird on your Mac can access data on an external drive, so there is no need to install Thunderbird on an external drive. Just install it in Applications on your Mac.

Data is stored in profiles. You can create a profile on your external drive, import the mbox files by copying or moving them into your profile in the file system (not in Thunderbird, but you could do that too), and tell the Thunderbird app to use that profile.

how do I make sure TB knows that the data from the mbox(es) I import should "live" on the external drive as well?

I'm not sure that I understand. Are you expecting to end up with two instances of the data? After you import into Apple Mail, you will want only one instance of the data on the external drive. It will be in your Thunderbird profile and that will be the only place where Thunderbird accesses it.

Thunderbird never needs to know about any external e-mail accounts, including gmail.

Is this the approach that you want to take? You may need more information for each step of this process. Please ask again if you do, OK?
creator: mozilla98

content:
From my understanding you want to backup all your emails to your usb drive and keep only a limited number of emails on your local drive of your computer and your email provider is gmail.

If this is the case then you would need 2 profiles, one you already have on your local so you need to create a second profile (let's call it USB profile) and point that profile to your USB drive. The USB profile needs to be configured as POP3 mail (rather than IMAP) and "leave email on server" (do not delete). Since you did not delete any email yet, all you have to do is start another instance of Thunderbird with USB profile and download all your current emails. You need to edit your profiles.ini to tell thunderbirds that it is on USB drive. Unfortunately I don't work with Macs so I don't know the location of profiles.ini file.

Here is a sample line in profiles.ini on windows ( Path variable tells thunderbird the physical location of the profile, you need to substitute it with you Mac USB drive path ).


[Profile1] Name=USB-Drive IsRelative=0 Path=V:\appdata\Thunderbird\Profiles\default


Before deleting any email using the main profile, make sure that they are already downloaded on USB profile.

You can run 2 instances of Thunderbird at the same times.

You can run some tests before doing actual cleanup. Example : send to yourself a test email, make sure that it's been downloaded to USB profile. Then delete from your main profile. Go back to your USB profile to see if it's still there.

content:
I think that I understand everything now.

I've used Macs for almost forty years, but have never installed apps outside the application folder. Whether or not Thunderbird can be installed on an external drive probably depends on the components that Thunderbird installs in different places of the local drive. See the attached screenpic. Caches and plist may be particularly important. I don't know if it is possible to make Thunderbird access such things if it is not installed in the Applications folder.

You have probably already read: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/installing-thunderbird-on-mac

Importing into Apple Mail may have failed because you tried to import everything at once. If you requested individual mboxes in your latest Takeout request, you may be able to import those smaller mboxes into Apple Mail.

content:
A plus address is a whole name email address. That is how it comes to be delivered, because it is an entirely complete and valid address. So of course it is not in your address book, another email address for the same person is in the address book and the two addresses are not associated in any way.

I do however see your point that it should be supported so I have filed an enhancement bug requesting it as well as updating an ancient request for overall support. We will see how that goes. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1983434
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
You have two options. 1. Allow it so Thunderbird can actually work. 2. Disallow it and remove the account from Thunderbird because it will not be functional so having it set up serves no purpose at all.

You will be prompted for access every time Thunderbird attempts to get mail (default to every 15 minutes) or if you choose the option when setting up your account synchronize your contacts (every 30 minutes) or calendar, (also every 30 minutes). As I said above you have two option of stopping requests.

There are occasions when things like VPN's and antivirus software causes previously allowed access to be revoked by Google. This is particularly so with the use of a VPN to hide your location from google. Your VPN says you are in Budapest and your phone also connected to google says you are in Atlanta. That rings alarms at google about you being hacked. Instant revocation of oauth tokens and a re-authentication is used to ensure you are actually you.

So I do not knowe how you need to stop it, my gut tells me you have a VPN issue but I don't know.
creator: MattAuSupport
